derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English mandrag(g) e, from Middle Dutch mandrag(r) e, from medieval Latin mandragora; associated with man (because of the shape of its root) + drake in the Old English sense 'dragon'

means.word_mean: 1. the root of the mandrake plant; used medicinally or as a narcotic
2. a plant of southern Europe and North Africa having purple flowers, yellow fruits and a forked root formerly thought to have magical powers
